text:
ﬁnite number of entries. We can think of a vectorx∈Rn as function with
nfunction values. The concept of an inner product can be generalized to
vectors with an inﬁnite number of entries (countably inﬁnite) and also
continuous-valued functions (uncountably inﬁnite). Then the sum over
individual components of vectors (see Equation (3.5) for example) turns
into an integral.
An inner product of two functions u : R →R and v : R →R can be
deﬁned as the deﬁnite integral
⟨u,v⟩:=
∫ b
a
u(x)v(x)dx (3.37)
